subject: Re: [junit] Re: class isolation and class order for testing
msgSnippet: ... Yes.  That s exactly what a mock object is: an object that verifies that it is being used as expected by the object under test and fails the test if it is
messageBody:
On 15/01/2008, csabcsi.szucs <csaba.szucs@...> wrote:
> So how and where do the tests express how the object calls out through
> the interface?
> Maybe in the mock implementation by doing some assertions on the
> arguments of the interface-method? So are you allowed to put part of
> your assertions other than the test method-body in JUnit?

Yes. That's exactly what a mock object is: an object that verifies
that it is being used as expected by the object under test and fails
the test if it is not.

You can put your assertions anywhere that is convenient. I often pull
assertions into supporting methods or objects as I refactor my tests.

--Nat
